item.title: New project
item.description: Exciting news! I'm in the process of building Routeshuffle, a user-friendly website for generating random routes for running, biking, and walking. Unlike existing competitors, Routeloop and MapMyRun’s Route Genius, Routeshuffle aims to offer a refreshing, feature-rich experience with easy route exporting and more. I'm developing it using Node.js on a Chromebook, and I’m eager to share my journey. Stay tuned for updates as I work towards launching this tool early next year!

item.title: Touring Google
item.description: Join me on an exciting journey to Los Angeles after winning a video contest with Mentor Foundation USA! Our adventure included an unforgettable tour of Google’s Venice Beach office and the YouTube Space. From vibrant workspaces and free healthy meals to unique perks like on-site laundry and a dog park, I discovered what makes Google a prime workplace. The day concluded at a delightful Swedish restaurant, celebrating success and inspiration. A huge thanks to everyone who made this incredible experience possible!

item.title: Bump
item.description: In this reflection on indoor track meets, a high school runner shares the intense emotions experienced during competitive races. Battling poor air quality and distractions from spectators, the runner confronts feelings of anger and determination, dubbing it "Run Rage." A memorable moment arises during a cross-country race when an unwitting spectator’s phone dangles over the fence, leading to an unexpected encounter. This experience highlights the complex nature of racing, revealing how different versions of ourselves emerge in high-pressure situations. Ultimately, it’s a journey of self-discovery through competition and the chaos that surrounds it.

item.title: WWDC scholarship
item.description: Reflecting on my unforgettable experience at WWDC 2019, I share my journey from a novice in Swift to winning an Apple scholarship. Inspired by the stories of past scholars, I dedicated countless hours to develop a playground project—a traffic simulator that used pathfinding and natural language processing. Through intense research, brainstorming, and community support, I created an interactive demo that showcased my growth. The thrill of receiving the acceptance email made the hard work worth it. I encourage all aspiring developers to apply for this incredible opportunity—it's a life-changing experience!

item.title: Virus
item.description: In March 2020, as the world grappled with the emergence of the coronavirus, Chris Cuomo delivered a stark message about the inevitable changes to our daily lives. With schools and sports facing cancellations and travel restrictions looming, he urged listeners to come together and act responsibly. As a high school senior, the uncertainty stirred emotions of anger and fear, highlighting the profound impact of the virus on personal freedoms and social structures. This moment marked a turning point, emphasizing the need for unity and proactive measures to combat the pandemic.

item.title: Schools Gone
item.description: In the wake of COVID-19, school has shifted to home for the next month, bringing unexpected challenges and isolation. As I adapt to remote learning, I find comfort in sharing a workspace with my sister while reminiscing about the memories made during my high school years. A solo run to the track becomes a moment of reflection, highlighting the significance of the experiences I once took for granted. Though I hold onto hope for normalcy, the future feels uncertain, and the transition serves as a poignant reminder of what we've lost.

item.title: This Candidate Does Not Exist
item.description: In a thought-provoking experiment, a high school student created a fake congressional candidate, "Andrew Walz," to expose vulnerabilities in election integrity and social media verification. Using AI-generated imagery and minimal effort, the student successfully had Walz verified on Twitter and listed on Ballotpedia, raising concerns about the ease of impersonation in political campaigns. After reaching out to the media, the incident sparked discussions about transparency and accountability, prompting both Twitter and Ballotpedia to implement new verification measures. This experience highlighted the importance of vigilance in safeguarding democracy against misinformation.

item.title: Live streaming my high school graduation
item.description: In August 2020, I took on the challenge of live streaming my high school graduation in a unique "drive-thru" format due to the pandemic. With the support of school administration, I navigated the logistics of streaming using OBS and a T-Mobile hotspot, ensuring family and friends could virtually celebrate the day. From setting up multiple cameras to creating overlays of graduates' photos, my efforts culminated in a memorable 5.5-hour event. Over 3,000 viewers tuned in live, and I plan to leverage this experience to offer live streaming services to other schools in the future.

item.title: The bike lane
item.description: In a reflective post, a new NYC resident shares their biking journey through the city, highlighting both the joys and challenges of city cycling. They recount daily rides for fun and errands, navigating chaotic traffic and the unpredictable behavior of fellow cyclists and drivers. Despite close calls and the inherent dangers, including recent tragic incidents, they emphasize a cautious approach to biking. This personal narrative sheds light on the complexities of cycling safety in urban environments, leaving readers to ponder the risks that come with this vibrant mode of transportation.

item.title: Music memories
item.description: Reflecting on music’s power to evoke vivid memories, I discovered how each song in my Spotify library transports me to specific moments in time. From walking through Barnes and Noble with my mom to watching dash-cam videos in high school, these tracks encapsulate emotions tied to unique experiences. As I shuffle through my favorites, I’m reminded of how music serves as a powerful conduit for nostalgia, vividly bringing back past feelings and memories that are otherwise fleeting. Join me on this journey down memory lane through the soundtrack of my life.

item.title: Check & Go
item.description: In a reflective post, the author shares their first quiet run around Central Park's reservoir since dealing with a lingering foot injury. They reminisce about past racing mottos like "sit and kick" and "check and go," which help them focus on form. After analyzing their stride, they discover their injured left foot has been compensating, causing misalignment. As they consciously adjust their form during the run, they sense an improvement, signaling a hopeful step towards recovery and a newfound appreciation for evening runs amidst the city’s skyline.

item.title: Groceries
item.description: In this reflection on grocery shopping, the author embraces the freedom and variety of food available since living independently. A visit to a Texas grocery store in 1989 by Boris Yeltsin highlights the stark contrasts between life in the Soviet Union and the abundance found in America. Yeltsin’s astonishment at the sheer selection of goods fueled his disillusionment with communism, ultimately leading to significant economic reforms in Russia. This exploration of personal experience ties in unexpected historical impact, illustrating how something as simple as a grocery store visit can influence political change.

item.title: Following the rules
item.description: In this reflective post, the author shares their experience running around Central Park's reservoir, highlighting the challenges of navigating a crowded, one-way track amidst walkers. While acknowledging the awkwardness of enforcing social distancing rules, they touch upon the significance of running counter-clockwise, tying it to natural phenomena and unique athletic advantages. An encounter with a determined elderly man insisting on the rules prompts the author to appreciate his insistence, revealing a blend of humor and societal norms regarding rule enforcement in shared spaces.

item.title: When it's all over
item.description: In this reflective post, the author grapples with the ongoing impact of the coronavirus and the uncertainty of what life will look like in the future. As the fall season approaches and pandemic restrictions continue, the writer contemplates the changes in their perspective and daily life. Drawing parallels between their experiences and running, they express hope for the eventual end of the crisis while acknowledging the challenges of adapting to a new normal. The piece captures a blend of nostalgia, introspection, and the desire for a return to familiarity amid ongoing uncertainty.

item.title: Pictures
item.description: Reflecting on a scenic Amtrak journey through the Adirondacks, I encountered a deer submerged in the Hudson River. My impulse to capture the moment with my camera made me wonder about the societal pressure to document experiences for validation. Acknowledging the influence of technology and cultural norms, I grappled with the idea of prioritizing the experience over the need for photographic proof. This contemplation echoes Susan Sontag's observations on how people increasingly place cameras between themselves and the beauty around them, often losing the essence of the moment in the pursuit of image.

item.title: Passing by
item.description: In the dark chill of a track meet, the chaotic excitement of the 4x400 meter relay unfolds. Having already run their races, distance athletes embrace this grueling final stretch, pushing their limits amidst cheers and camaraderie. As one runner steps to the line, the initial roar fades into an isolating silence of determination, revealing that true effort often goes unnoticed. This race echoes life's journey—where the spotlight shines brightly at the start and finish, but the real struggle happens in the quiet perseverance in between.

item.title: Random Jobs
item.description: Join me on my journey as a Postmates delivery cyclist in NYC! I've embraced the thrill of cycling around the city while making deliveries from unique restaurants to various types of buildings. Each delivery, including my most random one—a drop-off of spiked ice cream at an NBC office—has taught me valuable lessons about logistics and the kindness of strangers. Mistakes happen, but the rewarding experiences keep me motivated. I’m passionate about exploring different part-time jobs to gain insights and perspectives I once dreamed of as a kid.

item.title: Perimeter
item.description: Last weekend, I embarked on a 36-mile journey around Manhattan's perimeter, taking nearly 12 hours and clocking over 65,000 steps! From scenic views along the Harlem River to navigating through unexpected detours and thunderstorms, each mile tested my endurance. While it wasn't a transformative experience, the adventure was thrilling and allowed me to appreciate the city from unique angles. Despite the blisters and sore feet, I’m proud to have tackled this challenge and would encourage fellow adventurers to walk the perimeter—just be prepared for the physical toll!

item.title: 2021: Year in Review
item.description: Reflecting on a transformative 2021, I secured an internship at MSCHF in a creative way, embraced new adventures in running and biking, and thrived in a vibrant co-living house in NYC. I tackled challenges like wiping out on my bike and built connections that enriched my life. From launching the app Overheard.me with friends to running track and cross country, each experience shaped my year. Despite obstacles like wallet mishaps and COVID, I'm eager for what the next chapter in NYC holds. Grateful for the journey and the people who've made it unforgettable!

item.title: 2022: Year in Review
item.description: Reflecting on an eventful 2022, I navigated challenges and adventures, from testing positive for COVID in London to exploring the stunning landscapes of Scotland and Germany. I immersed myself in diverse cultures, reconnected with my roots in Dresden, and relaunched my fitness website, Routeshuffle. As a web intern at Tendies, I honed my skills while enjoying collaborative living at Hack Lodge. I also tackled physical feats, like running for my college's cross-country team and biking 130 miles to Montauk. Grateful for cherished memories and experiences, I welcomed the New Year in Lisbon with family.

item.title: Unclaimed property
item.description: In our exploration of unclaimed property, we delved into the challenge of recovering funds owed to individuals and businesses due to forgotten accounts and inactive assets. With over $100 billion unclaimed, the lack of awareness presents a significant hurdle. While some states allow bounty hunters to help claimants for a fee, our outreach efforts faced skepticism and minimal conversion. The complex and fragmented nature of the industry, combined with limited incentives for governments, makes tackling this issue tough. We ultimately decided to step back, but the potential for innovation in this space remains vast and intriguing.

item.title: 2023: Year in Review
item.description: Reflecting on a transformative 2023, I navigated significant life changes, moving to San Francisco and diving into the startup world as a co-founder. Embracing "adulting" and leaving school for the first time, I learned more than ever about my agency and the vast experiences awaiting me. From exciting projects with friends to personal growth through therapy, every moment was filled with learning, laughter, and memorable adventures. As the year wraps up with family travels, I'm eager to explore new ideas and friendships in 2024. Grateful for the journey and looking forward to what’s next!

item.title: What a small world
item.description: Explore the fascinating connections in our lives through a deep dive into social networks! This post highlights the joy of discovering shared acquaintances by scraping Instagram data to uncover links between friends from different parts of life. With 217,723 relationships visualized, the author reveals surprising overlaps and amusing stories that showcase how interconnected we truly are. Join in on the name game and see just how small the world really is!

item.title: 2024: Year in Review
item.description: Reflecting on an eventful 2024, I tackled a 51-mile walk around San Francisco, cycled to LA, and launched a community scavenger hunt that captivated hundreds. I also solo-traveled to Japan, created engaging projects like an ambient navigation app, and managed some personal challenges, including back pain and a viral video experience. Celebrating natural beauty during a solar eclipse and leading fun activities like "freeze mob" events added joy to the year. With my startup thriving and new adventures on the horizon, I'm ready to embrace 2025 with enthusiasm!
